Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Doubling Cellular Capacity by Full Duplex Communications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Traditional radio transceivers are generally not able to receive and transmit on the same frequency band because of the crosstalk between the transmitter and the receiver circuits. Given that the received signal over the air is one million times or more weaker than the transmitted signal, it is very difficult, if not impossible, to detect the received signal under internal interference from the transmitter. Thus, to avoid this interference, today's communication systems rely on half duplex transmission, typically transmitting and receiving at different times or in different frequency bands. The full duplex technology developed in this project allows for transceivers to receive and transmit in the same frequency band, at the same time, potentially doubling data rates. Given the enormous market size of the wireless industry, combined with the pressing need for solutions to solve the 'spectrum crunch', full duplex technology thus offers tremendous societal and commercial impact.

This project addresses the fundamental challenges when incorporating full duplex radios in a cellular network to unlock the full potential of this technology. Specifically, the project consists of three inter-related components: (i) a radio front-end design that allows multiple antenna gains in conjunction with full duplex operation; (ii) a smart scheduler for full duplex base stations that coordinates the maximum set of transmissions with least mutual interference, while maintaining fairness among the mobiles; (iii) a joint routing and scheduling algorithm that fully utilizes full duplex enabled relay terminals. The technologies developed span physical, medium access control, and network layers, and jointly coordinate the air-interface and the backhaul. The theory and algorithms will be validated by over-the-air and end-to-end experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traditional radio transceivers are generally not able to receive and transmit on the same frequency band due to crosstalk between the transmitter and the receiver circuits. With recent advances in signal processing and antenna interference cancellation technologies, researchers have proposed and built radio prototypes that allow simultaneous transmissions and receptions from the same radio. Such radios are called full duplex (FD) radios and can potentially double data rates.  


This project addresses the fundamental challenges when incorporating full duplex radios in a cellular network. As we discovered, when multiple FD radios operate at the same time in a radio network, excessive interference is generated over the air. Without carefully controlling interference, the potential gains of FD radios diminish quickly. To unlock the full potential of FD systems, user transmissions have to be carefully scheduled, and transmission powers have to be carefully selected, to avoid excessive interference. Specifically, the project consists of three inter-related components: 1) a radio front-end design that allows multiple antenna gains in conjunction with full duplex operation; 2) a smart scheduler for full duplex base stations that coordinates the maximum set of transmissions with least mutual interference, while satisfying various fairness criteria among the mobiles; 3) a joint routing and scheduling algorithm that fully utilizes full duplex enabled relay terminals. The technologies developed span physical, medium access control, and network layers, and jointly coordinate the air-interface and the backhaul.


The major outcomes of this project includes: 1) The team designed several algorithms that combines various types of opportunistic fair scheduling and power allocation to avoid excessive interference over-the-air, and allows FD radios to double the capacity of a cellular network; 2) With advanced interference cancellation techniques, over-the-air interference can be reduced after reception of the signal, which significantly improves the operation region for full duplex systems; 3) Traditional FD radios require traffic to be symmetric to maximize throughput multiplexing gains. FD can be employed to wirelessly relay traffic to a small cell base station, instead of using a fiber backhaul link. The team discovered that even when data traffic is unbalanced in the uplink and downlink direction, the proposed solution is able to double the capacity of the network; 4) A deep learning based algorithm is introduced to solve the user scheduling and power allocation problem in an FD network. Compared with exhaustive search, the neural network based algorithm achieves 10000X saving in computation cost, and is able to run at real-time in complex cellular networks. 5) Over four PhD level students and three master level students worked closely with the PI’s, including one female PhD student. 6) The team has published three journal papers, and over eight conference papers during the course of this project. One of the conference papers received the Best Paper Award at the IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC) 2016.


We collaborated with our industrial partner, InterDigital, Qualcomm, Sony and Verizon during the project, and submitted an application for a US patent with InterDigital. NYU is the only US university member of Next Generation Mobile Networks (NGMN), an alliance for mobile operators, equipment vendors, and research institutions. This work was presented at NGMN to a (mostly) industry audience, generating a positive response and helpful comments for us. It was also presented at NYU Wireless, at the Industry Board Meeting, and more informally at open houses.
